d16afa0ae7c.description: Mining the tech world for lively, meaningful tales. Part of WIRED Media Group.
d16afa0ae7c.name: Backchannel
d16afa0ae7c.shortDescription: Mining the tech world for lively, meaningful tales.

paragraphs.name: 403c
paragraphs.text: Those supporting this awful rollback say it’s about fair play (after all, services like Google and Facebook weren’t subject to the rule) and freedom. But no one is forced to use Google or Facebook, and those companies make their money from advertising. The ISPs often are monopolies in their region — and consumers pay them. Anyway, if Congress wants Google and Verizon to play by the same privacy rules, why not make it so no company can sell private information without permission?

Yet last week both the Senate and the House — overwhelmingly with Republican votes — voted to overturn those limits, and to ban the FCC from ever imposing them again. President Trump is expected to sign the legislation, permanently making the internet a place for rapacious data collecting from largely unwitting consumers. (Here’s a list of those who voted against your privacy; bookmark it for 2018!)
paragraphs.name: ae80

paragraphs.text: Those supporting this awful rollback say it’s about fair play (after all, services like Google and Facebook weren’t subject to the rule) and freedom. But no one is forced to use Google or Facebook, and those companies make their money from advertising. The ISPs often are monopolies in their region — and consumers pay them. Anyway, if Congress wants Google and Verizon to play by the same privacy rules, why not make it so no company can sell private information without permission?
paragraphs.name: 403c

paragraphs.text: No, the internet is not so much the wild, wild West anymore. Increasingly, it’s more like Westworld.
paragraphs.name: 4bc9

paragraphs.text: Handcuffing Cities to Telecom Giants: Right now, there are efforts underway in at least 17 states and at the FCC that would essentially privatize public rights of way, all in the name of 5G. One problem with that? 5G doesn’t exist yet. Susan Crawford explains why we should be very skeptical of anything done in its name.
paragraphs.name: a71b

b78b07eeeb22.title: “Why are ISPs often monopolies” is a question well worth asking.

paragraphs.text: “Why are ISPs often monopolies” is a question well worth asking.
paragraphs.name: 056a

paragraphs.text: Nothing has changed. The rule that the FCC made in October had not been implemented. Your information was being sold before without your permissions, it’s being sold now. Nothing has changed.
paragraphs.name: 6ee6

paragraphs.text: Except: you now know how bad it is and can use the same appropriate defenses that many of us have been using since the early 2000’s, when adtech started getting big.

8b3fed4c9277.title: Maybe I’m just old but I remember when the internet was a “superhighway” and we were all worried…

paragraphs.text: Maybe I’m just old but I remember when the internet was a “superhighway” and we were all worried about building/accessing the “on ramps” to the virtual autobahn.

paragraphs.text: Always to err on the side of commerce — and turn us who venture online into products rather than customers.

paragraphs.text: I recall in the late 90s when the attitude was that the internet could not be regulated because (hand-waving). How naive.

6f58f7390961.title: The sad thing is that there really isn’t an ideological reason for this, other than to poke Obama…

paragraphs.text: The sad thing is that there really isn’t an ideological reason for this, other than to poke Obama in the eye. It is knee-jerk opposition to anything the “other side” wants.
paragraphs.name: 174b

97644a71bd53.title: Larry Lessig warned that this day might come.

paragraphs.text: Larry Lessig warned that this day might come. And it has arrived. Earlier generations — naive folks who believed the Internet could never be regulated — must now eat their words.
paragraphs.name: 54ef

paragraphs.text: And the rest of us, what must we do? Well, I’m afraid to say that the rest of us are called to endure the social, political and technological cost…

paragraphs.text: Is it true that Google, Facebook, and others can already full exploit our data in the way that the ISPs now want to? If so, where is the outrage? Is there a reason to give Google and Facebook a pass on this?

paragraphs.text: Steven, I would welcome your input and criticism on our plan to use the need for 5G (and other next-gen mobility services) to finance the reconstruction of American infrastructure.
paragraphs.name: a1cb

paragraphs.text: This method would maintain the public right of way while leveraging it to deliver needful services in a way that makes roads financially self-sustaining.

41481320ed12.title: It’s my understanding that while Google and Facebook both are legally permitted to create policies…

paragraphs.text: It’s my understanding that while Google and Facebook both are legally permitted to create policies to sell customer data to the highest bidder, they emphatically don’t. In fact, here’s Facebook making a direct pledge: “No, we don’t sell any of your information to anyone and we never will.” Google’s information page on how ads work is headlined: “We…
